ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I definitely think my all-around Spanish abilities, and my speaking abilities in particular, improved a lot over the course of this class
In this course we further developed the skills and grammar we learned in Span110. We also learned more conjugations and vocabulary!

All of the connecting information that L1 taught me. L1 was the foundation, but it was in L2 that I actually learned the important connections that gave me a comprehensive understanding of the Spanish language. L2 was the class in which I truly learned how to speak Spanish.
This course taught me valuable skills in memorization and problem solving (i.e., finding new methods of thinking through grammar constructs I didn't initially understand).
I improved my Spanish.
I developed better study habits after taking this course and improved my conversational skills.
Further developed my Spanish comprehension and speaking abilities, along with a greater understanding of culture in Spanish-speaking countries.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A lot of busy work for this class but generally helpful for learning spanish. Some assignments felt very high school though. Wish a little more though went into how best to learn new material.

I think the activities can sometimes be a bit much and I personally did not find a lot of value in the unit discussing art, I think the course does a good job of helping students better understand both the language of Spanish and the cultures of Spanish-speaking countries.

The strengths are that it really helps you to learn spanish quickly. You are practicing so often that your growth is pretty rapid. The weakness is being cold-called in class sometimes, but thats not necessarily a bad thing. Also, there is a lot of content really fast so you need to keep up.

Strengths are certainly the course organization, with everything organized week by week in the modules tab. This way, even with occasional lack of clarity on instructions because of the language barrier, I always knew what we were supposed to be doing. A weakness of the class was its location, in the Bass basement. Especially in a class that meets 4 times a week, being in the Bass basement was sincerely unideal. Another weakness may be the length of the asynchronous activities on asynchronous days. These would often take longer than the class period would have and sometimes put me behind in my other classes.
This course was very strong in that my Spanish has drastically improved. However, I don't recommend hosting it in Bass Library where I once couldn't attend class because of an ID problem.
Some assignments should be reviewed to determine whether theyre really worth our time.

This course was well-organized and offered an extensive learning experience of Spanish. However, it was very overwhelming to the point where I found things counterproductive. Not everyone in the class was at the same level, and some students had been learning Spanish for years longer than other students, but there wasn't much put in place to minimize these gaps in understanding.

Strengths - Interesting material taught through engaging methods.

Weaknesses - Some assignments seem to provide little benefit to the student.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, specifically with Pilar
Yes. The Spanish classes are definitely a lot of work, and it's obviously not ideal to have four class meetings a week for one class, but Pilar really did make class time enjoyable.
Yes! If youve taken L1, or just placed in L2, its a good course to take if you are willing to put in a little time.

Yes, but it is very tough. L2 is known to be quite rigorous and this is the case. But you WILL learn Spanish in this class. It is a lot of work and quite difficult to keep up at some times but you will absolutely learn to speak Spanish and take important steps toward fluency.
Yes, as it is well taught and teaches you valuable lessons related to language learning.
I would recommend this course to another student if they have the time in their schedule to put the work in and are genuinely interested in learning the language.
Yes. This is a great course to improve your Spanish understanding/speaking abilities taught by a great professor.
